citation.article-title: Thiohalospira halophila gen. nov., sp. nov. and Thiohalospira alkaliphila sp. nov., novel obligately chemolithoautotrophic, halophilic, sulfur-oxidizing gammaproteobacteria from hypersaline habitats.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Thiohalospira alkaliphila sp. nov.
Thiohalospira alkaliphila [al.ka.li.phi′la. M.L. n. alkali soda ash (from Arabic al-qalyi the ashes of saltwort); Gr. adj. philos loving; N.L. fem. adj. alkaliphila loving alkaline conditions].
Exhibits the following properties in addition to those given in the genus description.
Cells are spirilla of variable length, 0.4–0.5×2–4 μm, with single polar flagella.
Cells contain high concentrations of a yellow pigment in the membranes.
Obligately microaerophilic; no growth occurs above 10 % O2 in the gas phase, the optimum concentration being 2 %.
Oxidizes thiosulfate and sulfide to sulfate with the occasional formation of elemental sulfur.
Does not produce tetrathionate from thiosulfate.
Moderately halophilic, with a salinity range for growth from 0.5 to 4.0 M NaCl and an optimum at 2.0 M.
Requires high concentrations of both Na+ and Cl−.
Facultatively alkaliphilic with a pH range for growth between 7.0 and 10.2 and an optimum at pH 8.5.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 65.6 mol% (Tm).
The type strain, ALgr 6spT (=DSM 17116T=UNIQEM U372T), was isolated from sediments of hypersaline alkaline lakes at Wadi El Natrun in Egypt by means of sulfide–oxygen gradient cultivation.
